text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
LES ECHOS
-- President Jacques Chirac terms Renault's approach to the Vilvoorde shutdown "shocking" as Prime Minister Alain Juppe demands more social action on the lay-offs.
-- European Commission chairman Jacques Santer says, with King Albert II in the audience, Vilvoorde shutdown "strikes a hard blow at trust among Europeans"
-- Thomson-CSF posts 745 million franc annual net profit.
-- Air Liquide 1996 profit up 4.2 percent at 2.77 billion francs.
-- BSN Emballage sell-off rumours spur Danone share price upwards.
-- Accor to sell 11.5 percent of Compass stake for 2.4 billion francs.
LA TRIBUNE
-- Juppe puts pressure on Renault chairman Louis Scweitzer to appease Belgians with lay-off benefits.
-- Civil servants stage one-day walkout today to protest government's refusal to open wage negotiations.
L'AGEFI
-- Paris Bourse hits record high just under 2,700 threshold.
-- Axa-UAP is rumoured to have informed the authorities it will cut its BNP stake to under 10 percent.
-- Credit Immobilier ends eight-month wait to take over Credit Foncier but says it is still interested "in principle".
LE FIGARO
-- Juppe wants "a period of concerted action" and "alternatives" over the Vilvoorde shutdown.
LIBERATION (Economic section)
-- Juppe criticises Schweitzer but does not question the shutdown decisions themselves.
-- Civil servants on strike for higher wages today.
THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
-- EU urges workers to sue Renault over lay-offs as Schweitzer suggests talks on lay-off benefits and conversion of the Vilvoorde plant.
